Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Medium: Collaborative Research: Scalable Learning of Nonlinear Models in Large Neural Populations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Fundamental to understanding information processing in the brain are methods that can systematically characterize the structure and dynamics of neural circuits that underlie perception and cognition. Micro- electrocorticography (µECoG) is the practice of using microelectrodes placed directly on the exposed surface of the brain to record electrical activity from the cerebral cortex. Recent advances in µECoG provide unique opportunities to observe large regions of the neural cortex at unprecedented spatial and temporal resolution. However, uncovering the structure of complex neural circuits is challenging. This interdisciplinary project develops methods for learning high-dimensional nonlinear systems with a particular focus on these systems as they arise in cortical networks and validates these techniques on state-of-the-art µECoG systems.

Three thrusts are considered: The first considers the general problem of state estimation in high-dimensional dynamical systems using decomposition methods including distributed Kalman and particle filtering and graphical models. The main goal is to provide computationally scalable and flexible approaches with provable guarantees. The second combines these state estimation methods with Bayesian parameter estimation and compressed sensing techniques to identify connectivity and nonlinear dynamics in the networks. The third validates these methods on identification of neural models from µECoG arrays. Applications to neural mapping, auditory and visual stimuli decoding are explored. In particular, the project seeks to demonstrate the method on using recordings from rat primary auditory cortex and cat visual cortex using a novel, flexible, high-resolution electrode array.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we have studied the microscale electrophysiology of epilepsy, specifically looking for better biomarkers of epileptic tissue. We applied automated detectors and machine learning algorithms to identify high frequency oscillations (HFOs), interictal epileptiform discharges (IEDs), and high-frequency broadband (HFB) neural activity. We analyzed micro-electrocorticographic (µECoG) data from human cortex during epilepsy surgery, which was collected under a different effort. We found that microelectrodes in our arrays have improved resolution and signal to noise ratios (SNR) to detect microscale events.  By developing these tools, we will be better able to identify abnormal brain activity and epileptic networks in the brain. Removing or disrupting these abnormal networks will be key to improving the outcome of epilepsy surgery and improving the performance of next generation implantable anti-epileptic devices.

In parallel, we have developed and extensively tested novel electrode arrays based on thin-film (TF) technology using liquid crystal polymer (LCP) to meet the need for high-resolution human neural interfaces to enable discovery science and advance clinical therapies. Our LCP-TF electrodes replace and improve upon current subdural electrodes (SDE) and stereoelectroencephalographic electrodes (SEEG) by incorporating high-density microelectrodes, while retaining clinical-standard macroelectrodes. Our LCP-TF arrays have 25× higher electrode density and 20× higher channel count than conventional SDE and SEEG electrodes. LCP-TF electrodes are also thinner (~200 µm total thickness) and 5× more flexible than conventional SDE. They achieve higher signal to noise ratio (SNR) for high frequency signals than conventional SDE and SEEG, and offer the capability of patterned microstimulation over large cortical areas. While standard TF electrode arrays are expensive to manufacture, our LCP-TF electrodes are low cost because they leverage medical-grade, commercial, flexible circuit manufacturing. Our miniaturized data acquisition systems amplify and digitize neural signals near the electrodes to reduce wiring burden and eliminate artifacts, providing higher quality neural recordings with improved safety. Low-cost, FDA-approved, high-density LCP-TF electrodes will provide a multitude of advances in brain research including improved treatment of pharmacologically resistant epilepsy, accelerated discoveries in basic science, and high performance motor, speech, visual, and auditory prostheses.
